Decentralized Federated Learning via
Non-Coherent Over-the-Air Consensus

NicolÃ² Michelusi N. Michelusi is with the School of Electrical, Computer and Energy Engineering, Arizona State University.An extended version of this work appears in [1].This research has been funded in part by NSF under grant CNS-2129615.
Abstract

This paper presents NCOTA-DGD, a Decentralized Gradient Descent (DGD) algorithm that combines local gradient descent with a novel Non-Coherent Over-The-Air (NCOTA) consensus scheme to solve distributed machine-learning problems over wirelessly-connected systems. NCOTA-DGDÂ leverages the waveform superposition properties of the wireless channels: it enables simultaneous transmissions under half-duplex constraints, by mapping local optimization signals to a mixture of preamble sequences, and consensus via non-coherent combining at the receivers. NCOTA-DGDÂ operates without channel state information at transmitters and receivers, and leverages the average channel pathloss to mix signals, without explicit knowledge of the mixing weights (typically known in consensus-based optimization algorithms). It is shown both theoretically and numerically that, for smooth and strongly-convex problems with fixed consensus and learning stepsizes, the updates of NCOTA-DGDÂ converge in Euclidean distance to the global optimum with rate ğ’ªâ€‹(Kâˆ’1/4)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ¾14\mathcal{O}(K^{-1/4}) for a target of Kğ¾K iterations. NCOTA-DGDÂ is evaluated numerically over a logistic regression problem, showing faster convergence vis-Ã -vis running time than implementations of the classical DGD algorithm over digital and analog orthogonal channels.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [2] has emerged as a new paradigm to alleviate the communication burden and privacy concerns associated with the transmission of raw data to a ML server, by leveraging decentralized computational and communication resources at the edge of the network. Typically, it aims to solve

ğ°âˆ—=argâ€‹minğ°âˆˆâ„dâ¡Fâ€‹(ğ°)â‰œ1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(ğ°)superscriptğ°subscriptargminğ°superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ¹ğ°â‰œ1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ°\displaystyle{\mathbf{w}}^{*}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\ F(\mathbf{w})\triangleq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(\mathbf{w}) (P)

among Nğ‘N edge devices, where fiâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ°f_{i}(\mathbf{w}) is the empirical loss based on the local dataset of node iğ‘–i (known to iğ‘–i alone), and ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w} is a dğ‘‘d-dimensional parameter vector, so that Fâ€‹(ğ°)ğ¹ğ°F(\mathbf{w}) represents the empirical loss over the network. Conventional FL solves (P) based on a client-server architecture, where the Nğ‘N nodes interact with a parameter server (PS, such as a base station) over multiple rounds [3]: in each round, edge devices compute local gradients based on a global model broadcast by the PS, and transmit them to the PS; the latter aggregates the local gradients and updates the global model via gradient descent.

Yet, in many important scenarios, a PS may be lacking [4], or direct communication with the PS may be challenging due to severe channel propagation conditions. In these cases, a decentralized learning architecture may be more attractive, in which the edge devices communicate with each other without the aid of a PS [4]. A renowned algorithm to solve (P) in this setting is Decentralized Gradient Descent (DGD) [5]: at iteration kğ‘˜k, each node (iğ‘–i) updates its local optimization signal ğ°i,ksubscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘˜\mathbf{w}_{i,k} by combining a consensus signal ğœi,ksubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘˜\mathbf{c}_{i,k} (weighted sum of the neighborsâ€™ signals) with a local gradient step, as

ğ°i,k+1subscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘˜1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{i,k+1} =ğ°i,k+âˆ‘j=1NÏ‰i,jâ€‹(ğ°j,kâˆ’ğ°i,k)âŸâ‰œğœi,kâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ°i,k);absentsubscriptâŸsubscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ”ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ°ğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘˜â‰œabsentsubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœ‚âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘˜\displaystyle=\underbrace{\mathbf{w}_{i,k}+\sum_{j=1}^{N}\omega_{i,j}(\mathbf{w}_{j,k}-\mathbf{w}_{i,k})}_{\triangleq\mathbf{c}_{i,k}}-\eta\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i,k}); (1)

here, Ï‰i,jsubscriptğœ”ğ‘–ğ‘—\omega_{i,j} are non-negative mixing weights with Ï‰i,j=Ï‰j,isubscriptğœ”ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğœ”ğ‘—ğ‘–\omega_{i,j}{=}\omega_{j,i} and âˆ‘j=1NÏ‰i,j=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ”ğ‘–ğ‘—1\sum_{j=1}^{N}\omega_{i,j}{=}1 (Ï‰i,j=0subscriptğœ”ğ‘–ğ‘—0\omega_{i,j}{=}0 if iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j do not communicate directly).

Nevertheless, (1) relies on communications over orthogonal, noise- and error-free links, and on knowledge of the mixing weights to aggregate the incoming signals. In many practical scenarios (e.g., swarms of UAVs), communications occur over wireless links: interference from simultaneous transmissions, fading and noise may preclude the ability to receive error-free signals. Mitigating these sources of errors typically requires: 1) centralized coordination of network scheduling and interference management operations; 2) channel state information (CSI) to compensate signal fluctuations and link outages due to fading. Yet, such coordination may be non-trivial in wireless decentralized systems, and CSI acquisition may be impaired by pilot contamination and a source of severe overhead.

This calls for the design of decentralized optimization schemes that operate over (and leverage properties of) wireless channels. In this paper, we present NCOTA-DGD, an implementation of (1) over wireless channels subject to noise, fading, and interference. Its main feature is a Non-Coherent (NC)-Over-the-Air (OTA) consensus step that leverages the waveform superposition properties of the wireless channels, without the need for CSI at transmitters and receivers, and without explicit knowledge of the mixing weights. We show theoretically and numerically that, for smooth and strongly-convex problems with suitable constant consensus and learning stepsizes, the error (Euclidean distance) between the local models and the solution of (P) converges to zero with rate ğ’ªâ€‹(Kâˆ’1/4)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ¾14\mathcal{O}(K^{-1/4}) for a target of Kğ¾K iterations.

Recent OTA-based schemes under client-server [6, 7, 8, 9, 10] and decentralized [11, 12, 13] FL rely on accurate CSI and careful power control to compensate signal fluctuations due to fading. Focusing on decentralized FL, the works [11, 12, 13] use graph coloring to break down the network into smaller non-interfering subgraphs, in which one device operates as the PS. This expedient enables the use of techniques developed for client-server FL (including channel inversion) coupled with a suitable consensus enforcing step. Yet, these schemes rely on CSI and power control to invert channels, scheduling operations (e.g., graph coloring), and knowledge of the network structure and mixing weights Ï‰i,jsubscriptğœ”ğ‘–ğ‘—\omega_{i,j} for consensus. In contrast, NCOTA-DGDÂ overcomes this need by using a set of orthogonal preamble sequences to encode signals, coupled with non-coherent combining at the receivers; it leverages the channel pathloss to mix signals, without explicit knowledge of the mixing weights. The paper [14] studies consensus over a shared multipath channel. While it assumes the channels to be noiseless and static, our work focuses on decentralized optimization over noisy, time-varying fading channels.

The preamble-based technique developed in this paper is inspired by the preamble-based random access scheme developed in [15] to encode local gradients in client-server FL. The scheme therein relies on noise-free downlink and inversion of the average pathloss at the transmitters. Differently from [15]: 1) NCOTA-DGDÂ operates in decentralized settings, with all links subject to fading and noise; 2) instead of random access-based preamble selection of [15], NCOTA-DGDÂ maps local signals deterministically to a suitable linear combination of preamble sequences; 3) rather than inverting channels, NCOTA-DGDÂ  leverages the average pathloss to mix signals.

This paper is organized as follows. In Sec.Â II, we describe NCOTA-DGD, followed by its convergence analysis in Sec.Â III. In Sec.Â IV, we present numerical results, followed by concluding remarks in Sec.Â V. An extended version of this work appears in [1], including complete proofs, a more general and non-trivial analysis with decreasing stepsizes, more general fading models and frequency selective channels, stochastic gradient descent updates and extensive numericalÂ evaluations.

II System Model and NCOTA-DGD

We consider Nğ‘N wirelessly-connected edge devices, solving (P) via a noisy version of DGD in (1). We assume that the optimizer of (P), ğ°âˆ—superscriptğ°\mathbf{w}^{*}, lies in a dğ‘‘d-dimensional sphere ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W} of radius Rğ‘…R, within which the optimization is restricted (without loss of generality, centered at ğŸ0\mathbf{0}). For instance, for strongly-convex Fâ€‹(â‹…)ğ¹â‹…F(\cdot) with strong-convexity parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu, as assumed in the convergence analysis of Sec.Â III, since âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)=ğŸâˆ‡ğ¹superscriptğ°0\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{*}){=}\mathbf{0}, it holds â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğŸ)â€–=â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğŸ)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â€–â‰¥Î¼â€‹â€–ğŸâˆ’ğ°âˆ—â€–normâˆ‡ğ¹0normâˆ‡ğ¹0âˆ‡ğ¹superscriptğ°ğœ‡norm0superscriptğ°\|\nabla F(\mathbf{0})\|{=}\|\nabla F(\mathbf{0}){-}\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\|{\geq}\mu\|\mathbf{0}{-}\mathbf{w}^{*}\|, hence ğ’²â‰¡{ğ°âˆˆâ„d:â€–ğ°â€–â‰¤R}ğ’²conditional-setğ°superscriptâ„ğ‘‘normğ°ğ‘…\mathcal{W}{\equiv}\{\mathbf{w}{\in}\mathbb{R}^{d}{:}\|\mathbf{w}\|{\leq}R\}, where Râ‰œ1Î¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğŸ)â€–â‰œğ‘…1ğœ‡normâˆ‡ğ¹0R{\triangleq}\frac{1}{\mu}\|\nabla F(\mathbf{0})\| may be initially estimated via a consensus phase.

To solve (P) iteratively, we divide time into frames of fixed duration Tğ‘‡T. In frame kğ‘˜k, node iğ‘–i generates the transmission signal ğ±i,ksubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}_{i,k} using the Preamble-based Encoding procedure of Sec.Â II-A, and transmits it over the wireless channel. Upon receiving the signal from the other nodes in the network (Sec.Â II-B), it then computes a consensus signal using the Non-Coherent Over-the-Air procedure of Sec.Â II-C; finally, it updates the local optimization variable by combining the consensus signal with local gradient descent (Sec.Â II-D). Due to randomness of noise and fading, this procedure induces a stochastic process defined on a proper probability space; we denote by â„±ksubscriptâ„±ğ‘˜\mathcal{F}_{k} the Ïƒğœ\sigma-algebra consisting of all signals generated up to frame kğ‘˜k excluded, along with ğ°i,ksubscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘˜\mathbf{w}_{i,k}.

II-B Transmission over the wireless channel

Each node then transmits its signal ğ±i,ksubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}_{i,k} over the wireless channel. We assume Î›i,j=Î›j,isubscriptÎ›ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptÎ›ğ‘—ğ‘–\Lambda_{i,j}=\Lambda_{j,i} (channel reciprocity). Furthermore, hi,jksuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜h_{i,j}^{k} is i.i.d. over kğ‘˜k, and independent across iğ‘–i-jğ‘—j.

We assume that the nodes operate under a half-duplex constraint. We thus divide each frame of duration Tğ‘‡T into 222 slots; each node is assigned to transmit in only one of the 222 slots, and operates in receive mode in the other slot. This assignment is kept fixed during the entire optimization session, and may be done randomly by each node. II-C Non-Coherent Over-the-Air Consensus

ğ”¼â€‹[ği,k|â„±k]=Î›âˆ—â€‹âˆ‘j=1NÏ‰i,jâ€‹(ğ°j,kâˆ’ğ°i,k).ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptâ„±ğ‘˜superscriptÎ›superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ”ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ°ğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘˜\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[{\mathbf{d}}_{i,k}|\mathcal{F}_{k}]=\Lambda^{*}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\omega_{i,j}(\mathbf{w}_{j,k}-{\mathbf{w}}_{i,k}). We can see that ği,ksubscriptğğ‘–ğ‘˜\mathbf{d}_{i,k} represents a noisy consensus signal reminiscent of (1), which aggregates and averages the local signals of all the other nodes in the network, with mixing weights Ï‰i,jsubscriptğœ”ğ‘–ğ‘—\omega_{i,j} proportional to the average pathloss Î›i,jsubscriptÎ›ğ‘–ğ‘—\Lambda_{i,j}.

II-D Local optimization state update

Finally, node iğ‘–i updates ğ°i,ksubscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘˜\mathbf{w}_{i,k} by combining the consensus signal with a local gradient descent (computed in parallel with transmission and reception), followed by a projection onto ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W}, yielding the NCOTA-DGDÂ update

ğ°i,k+1=Î â€‹[ğ°i,k+Î³â€‹ği,kâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ°i,k)],subscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘˜1Î delimited-[]subscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ›¾subscriptğğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœ‚âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘˜\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{i,k+1}=\Pi[\mathbf{w}_{i,k}+\gamma{\mathbf{d}}_{i,k}-\eta\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i,k})], (11)

where Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0 and Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0 are consensus and learning stepsizes, respectively. As shown in Sec.Â III, these need to be chosen suitably, in order to mitigate the impact of fading and noise. The projection operator Î â€‹[ğš]Î delimited-[]ğš\Pi[\mathbf{a}] onto the sphere ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W} is defined as

Î â€‹[ğš]=argâ¡minğ°âˆˆğ’²â¡â€–ğ°âˆ’ğšâ€–={ğšifÂ â€‹â€–ğšâ€–â‰¤R,Râ€–ğšâ€–â€‹ğšotherwise,Î delimited-[]ğšsubscriptğ°ğ’²normğ°ğšcasesğšifÂ normğšğ‘…ğ‘…normğšğšotherwise\Pi[\mathbf{a}]=\arg\min_{\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}}\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{a}\|=\begin{cases}\mathbf{a}&\text{if }\|\mathbf{a}\|\leq R,\\ \frac{R}{\|\mathbf{a}\|}\mathbf{a}&\text{otherwise},\\ \end{cases}

and guarantees that ğ°i,kâˆˆğ’²,âˆ€i,âˆ€ksubscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ’²for-allğ‘–for-allğ‘˜\mathbf{w}_{i,k}\in\mathcal{W},\forall i,\forall k. The process described in Sec.Â II-A to Sec.Â II-D is then repeated in frame k+1ğ‘˜1k+1 with the new local optimization variable ğ°i,k+1subscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘˜1\mathbf{w}_{i,k+1}, and so on. A sketch of the overall NCOTA-DGDÂ algorithm is shown below:

We now express NCOTA-DGDÂ  as a noisy version of DGD in (1). âˆ’Î·âˆ‡fi(ğ°i,k)+Î³Ïµi,k].\displaystyle-\eta\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i,k})+\gamma\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i,k}\Big{]}. (12)

A few observations are in order:

  1. 1.

    The mixing weights satisfy Ï‰i,jâ‰¥0,âˆ€i,jsubscriptğœ”ğ‘–ğ‘—0for-allğ‘–ğ‘—\omega_{i,j}\geq 0,\forall i,j and Ï‰i,j=Ï‰j,isubscriptğœ”ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğœ”ğ‘—ğ‘–\omega_{i,j}=\omega_{j,i}, since Î›i,j=Î›j,isubscriptÎ›ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptÎ›ğ‘—ğ‘–\Lambda_{i,j}=\Lambda_{j,i} (channel reciprocity) and {jâˆˆğ’©i}â‡”{iâˆˆğ’©j}â‡”ğ‘—subscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğ‘–subscriptğ’©ğ‘—\{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}\}\Leftrightarrow\{i\in\mathcal{N}_{j}\}. Hence, [ğ›€]i,jâ‰œÏ‰i,jâ‰œsubscriptdelimited-[]ğ›€ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğœ”ğ‘–ğ‘—[\boldsymbol{\Omega}]_{i,j}\triangleq\omega_{i,j} is a symmetric, doubly-stochastic mixing matrix (as commonly assumed in consensus-based optimization [5]) induced by the large-scale propagation conditions of the channel.

  2. 2.

    When Î³=(Î›âˆ—)âˆ’1ğ›¾superscriptsuperscriptÎ›1\gamma{=}(\Lambda^{*})^{-1}, Ïµi,k=ğŸsubscriptbold-italic-Ïµğ‘–ğ‘˜0\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i,k}{=}\mathbf{0}, and neglecting the projection operation, (II-D) reduces to the DGD updates (1). Hence, NCOTA-DGDÂ can be interpreted as a projected DGD with noisy consensus. The consensus stepsize Î³ğ›¾\gamma helps mitigate the detrimental effect of error propagation due to noise and fading. Remarkably, unlike (1), no explicit knowledge of the mixing weights is required in NCOTA-DGD.

Since each frame includes 222 slots, and in each slot M=d+1ğ‘€ğ‘‘1M{=}d{+}1 samples are transmitted, the frame duration of NCOTA-DGDÂ is T=2â€‹(d+1)Wtâ€‹oâ€‹tğ‘‡2ğ‘‘1subscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡T=\frac{2(d+1)}{W_{tot}}, where Wtâ€‹oâ€‹tsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡W_{tot} is the bandwidth of the system.

IV Numerical Results

We solve the â€™0 versus 1â€™ task based on the MNIST dataset [16]: the goal is to distinguish images of digits â€™0â€™ and â€™1â€™.

Network deployment: We consider N=200ğ‘200N{=}200 nodes, spread uniformly at random over a region of 333km radius. The nodes communicate over a bandwidth of Wtâ€‹oâ€‹t=subscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡absentW_{tot}{=}1MHz, carrier frequency fc=3subscriptğ‘“ğ‘3f_{c}=3GHz, with a fixed transmission power of Ptâ€‹x=5subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¡ğ‘¥5P_{tx}=5dBm. The noise power spectral density at the receivers is N0=âˆ’169subscriptğ‘0169N_{0}=-169dBmW/Hz. The average pathloss Î›i,jsubscriptÎ›ğ‘–ğ‘—\Lambda_{i,j} between node iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j follows Friisâ€™ free space equation.

Data deployment: Each node has a local dataset with a single 28x28 pixels image: 100 nodes have digit â€™0â€™, the remainder have digit â€™1â€™. Node iğ‘–iâ€™s image is converted into a 50-dimensional real feature vector ğisubscriptğğ‘–\mathbf{d}_{i}, representing the components (out of a total of 28Ã—28=784282878428\times 28=784) with largest mean energy across the dataset, and then normalized to â€–ğiâ€–=1normsubscriptğğ‘–1\|\mathbf{d}_{i}\|=1. We define the label â„“i=1subscriptâ„“ğ‘–1\ell_{i}{=}1 if node iğ‘–iâ€™s image is of digit 0, otherwise â„“i=âˆ’1subscriptâ„“ğ‘–1\ell_{i}{=}-1.

Optimization problem formulation: We solve the task via regularized logistic regression, with loss function

fiâ€‹(ğ°)=0.012â€‹â€–ğ°â€–2+lnâ¡(1+expâ¡{âˆ’â„“iâ‹…ğiâŠ¤â€‹ğ°}),subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ°0.012superscriptnormğ°21â‹…subscriptâ„“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğğ‘–topğ°\displaystyle f_{i}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{0.01}{2}\|\mathbf{w}\|^{2}+\ln\left(1+\exp\{-\ell_{i}\cdot\mathbf{d}_{i}^{\top}\mathbf{w}\}\right), (18)

where ğ°âˆˆâ„dğ°superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is a d=50ğ‘‘50d=50-dimensional parameter vector. It can be shown that fiâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ°f_{i}(\mathbf{w}), hence the global function Fâ€‹(ğ°)=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(ğ°)ğ¹ğ°1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ°F(\mathbf{w}){=}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(\mathbf{w}), are all strongly-convex with parameter Î¼=0.01ğœ‡0.01\mu{=}0.01, and smooth with parameter L=Î¼+1/4ğ¿ğœ‡14L=\mu+1/4.

Wireless distributed optimization algorithms: We implement the following algorithms, all initialized as ğ°i,0=ğŸ,âˆ€isubscriptğ°ğ‘–00for-allğ‘–\mathbf{w}_{i,0}=\mathbf{0},\forall i.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet NCOTA-DGD (proposed): To enforce half-duplex constraints, 100 nodes, selected randomly, transmit in slot one, the others transmit in slot two. The frame duration is T=102â€‹Î¼ğ‘‡102ğœ‡T=102\mus.

We also compare the proposed NCOTA-DGDÂ with implementations of DGD over orthogonal digital (OD-DGD) and analog (OA-DGD) channels. Both follow the updates

In Fig.Â 1(a), we plot the best optimality error vis-Ã -vis running time: all algorithms are evaluated using a set of fixed stepsizes; for each time instance in the xğ‘¥x-axis, we plot only the optimality error evaluated on the best performing stepsize choice at that time. For NCOTA-DGD, we also show the curves for 3 representative stepsize choices. NCOTA-DGDÂ achieves the best performance, followed by OD-DGD and OA-DGD, thanks to its fast updates: during 500ms, NCOTA-DGDÂ performs 490049004900 iterations, versus only 22 of OD-DGD and 93 of OA-DGD, which are both limited by the use of orthogonal channels. Yet, OD-DGD bridges the gap to NCOTA-DGDÂ over time: this is due to its better noise-suppression capabilitiesâ€“especially beneficial when approaching convergence to ğ°âˆ—superscriptğ°\mathbf{w}^{*}. This behavior suggests that a mixed analog-digital strategy may further improve performanceâ€“a study left for future work. OA-DGD performs the worst: it does not enjoy the noise suppression capabilities of OD-DGD, and its updates are 53Ã—53\times slower than NCOTA-DGD. In Fig.Â 1(b), we plot the test error under the same best stepsize choice, vis-Ã -vis running time. It follows a similar trend as Fig.Â 1(a). Both NCOTA-DGDÂ and OD-DGD converge to the test error under the optimal ğ°âˆ—superscriptğ°\mathbf{w}^{*}.

In Fig.Â 1(c), we plot the best stepsizes Î·ğœ‚\eta (first row), Î³ğ›¾\gamma (second row) and best optimality error (third row) of NCOTA-DGD, for two different phases: initial phase, corresponding to the first âˆ¼similar-to\sim5k iterations (500500500ms, left side); asymptotic phase, after 26k iterations (right side). We note that, in the initial phase, the optimal Î·ğœ‚\eta and Î³ğ›¾\gamma do not match the theoretical behavior. In fact, in this regime, the optimality error is dominated by (17), and decreases quicker than ğ’ªâ€‹(Kâˆ’1/4)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ¾14\mathcal{O}(K^{-1/4}) (bottom left). Conversely, in the asymptotic phase, the optimal Î·ğœ‚\eta and Î³ğ›¾\gamma more closely match the theoretical scaling, and the optimality error decays as âˆ(K+Î´)âˆ’1/4proportional-toabsentsuperscriptğ¾ğ›¿14{\propto}(K{+}\delta)^{{-}1/4}, as predicted (with Î´=4227ğ›¿4227\delta=4227). This is in line with Corollary 1 when Ïµâ†’0â†’italic-Ïµ0{\epsilon}{\to}0, and corresponds to a regime when both error terms (16)-(17) are equally dominant.

V Conclusions

We presented NCOTA-DGD, an implementation of DGD that combines local gradient descent with a novel Non-Coherent Over-The-Air consensus scheme to solve distributed machine-learning problems over wirelessly-connected systems. NCOTA-DGDÂ  enables simultaneous transmissions by mapping local optimization signals to a mixture of preamble sequences, and consensus by correlating the received signals with the preamble sequences via non-coherent combining, without explicit knowledge of the mixing weights, nor channel state information. We proved its convergence properties, both theoretically and numerically, and showed superior performance than implementations of DGD over digital and analog orthogonal channels.
